query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 O insensata cura de’ mortali, 2 quanto son difettivi silogismi 3 quei che ti fanno in basso batter l’ali!
4 Chi dietro a iura e chi ad amforismi 5 sen giva, e chi seguendo sacerdozio, 6 e chi regnar per forza o per sofismi,
7 e chi rubare e chi civil negozio, 8 chi nel diletto de la carne involto 9 s’affaticava e chi si dava a l’ozio,
10 quando, da tutte queste cose sciolto, 11 con Bëatrice m’era suso in cielo 12 cotanto glorïosamente accolto.
query.result:
1 O senseless eagerness of mortals, 2 how defective are the syllogisms 3 that make you beat your wings downward!
4 One person went after laws and another after medical aphorisms, 5 and one followed the priesthood, 6 and one sought to rule by force or by trickery,
7 and one to steal and another to engage in business, 8 one toiled in the pleasures of the flesh 9 and another gave himself up to idleness,
10 when, freed from all these things, 11 with Beatrice I was welcomed up into Heaven 12 so gloriously.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Poi che ciascuno fu tornato ne lo 14 punto del cerchio in che avanti s’era, 15 fermossi, come a candellier candelo.
query.result: 13 After each one had returned to the 14 point of the circle where he had been before, 15 they stopped, like candles in a candlestick.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
16 E io senti’ dentro a quella lumera 17 che pria m’avea parlato, sorridendo 18 incominciar, faccendosi più mera:
19 «Così com’ io del suo raggio resplendo, 20 sì, riguardando ne la luce etterna, 21 li tuoi pensieri onde cagioni apprendo.
query.result:
16 And I heard within that light 17 that had spoken to me before, smiling 18 begin, becoming brighter:
19 “Just as I shine with its radiance, 20 so, gazing into the eternal light, 21 I learn the causes of your thoughts.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Tu dubbi, e hai voler che si ricerna 23 in sì aperta e ’n sì distesa lingua 24 lo dicer mio, ch’al tuo sentir si sterna,
25 ove dinanzi dissi: “U’ ben s’impingua”, 26 e là u’ dissi: “Non nacque il secondo”; 27 e qui è uopo che ben si distingua.
query.result:
22 You are in doubt, and you want my speech, 23 in such open and explicit language 24 that it may penetrate your understanding,
25 to be examined where I said earlier: “Where one fattens well”, 26 and where I said: “The second was not born”; 27 and here it is necessary to make a fine distinction.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 La provedenza, che governa il mondo 29 con quel consiglio nel quale ogne aspetto 30 creato è vinto pria che vada al fondo,
31 però che andasse ver’ lo suo diletto 32 la sposa di colui ch’ad alte grida 33 disposò lei col sangue benedetto,
34 in sé sicura e anche a lui più fida, 35 due principi ordinò in suo favore, 36 che quinci e quindi le fosser per guida.
query.result:
28 Providence, which governs the world 29 with that counsel in which every created 30 aspect is overcome before it reaches its end,
31 so that the bride of him who with loud cries 32 betrothed her with his blessed blood 33 might go toward her delight,
34 secure in herself and even more faithful to him, 35 ordained two princes in her favor, 36 who would be her guides on either side.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 L’un fu tutto serafico in ardore; 38 l’altro per sapïenza in terra fue 39 di cherubica luce uno splendore.

Please translate each line literally into English.
40 De l’un dirò, però che d’amendue 41 si dice l’un pregiando, qual ch’om prende, 42 perch’ ad un fine fur l’opere sue.
query.result: 40 I will speak of one, because of both 41 one is praised, whichever one is taken, 42 for their works were directed to the same end.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Intra Tupino e l’acqua che discende 44 del colle eletto dal beato Ubaldo, 45 fertile costa d’alto monte pende,
46 onde Perugia sente freddo e caldo 47 da Porta Sole; e di rietro le piange 48 per grave giogo Nocera con Gualdo.
query.result:
43 Between Tupino and the stream that descends 44 from the hill chosen by the blessed Ubald, 45 a fertile slope hangs from a high mountain,
46 from which Perugia feels the cold and heat 47 from Porta Sole; and behind it Nocera and Gualdo weep 48 because of the heavy yoke.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Di questa costa, là dov’ ella frange 50 più sua rattezza, nacque al mondo un sole, 51 come fa questo talvolta di Gange.
query.result: 49 From this slope, where it breaks 50 its steepness most, a sun was born into the world, 51 as this one sometimes does from the Ganges.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Però chi d’esso loco fa parole, 53 non dica Ascesi, ché direbbe corto, 54 ma Orïente, se proprio dir vuole.
query.result: 52 Therefore, whoever speaks of that place, 53 should not say Assisi, for that would be too short, 54 but Orient, if he wants to say it properly.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Ma perch’ io non proceda troppo chiuso, 74 Francesco e Povertà per questi amanti 75 prendi oramai nel mio parlar diffuso.
query.result: 73 But so that I may not proceed too obscurely, 74 now understand Francis and Poverty to be these lovers 75 in my expanded discourse.

76 Their harmony and their joyful countenances, 77 love and wonder and sweet gazes 78 made them a cause of holy thoughts;
79 so much so that the venerable Bernard 80 was the first to take off his shoes, and he ran after such peace 81 and, as he ran, it seemed to him that he was slow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 Oh ignota ricchezza! oh ben ferace! 83 Scalzasi Egidio, scalzasi Silvestro 84 dietro a lo sposo, sì la sposa piace.
query.result: 82 O unknown wealth! O fertile good! 83 Giles takes off his shoes, Sylvester takes off his shoes, 84 following the bridegroom, so pleasing is the bride.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Indi sen va quel padre e quel maestro 86 con la sua donna e con quella famiglia 87 che già legava l’umile capestro.
query.result: 85 Then that father and that teacher goes away 86 with his lady and with that family 87 that the humble cord was already binding.

88 Nor did the lowliness of his father's heart weigh down his brow, 89 for being the son of Pietro Bernardone, 90 nor for seeming wondrously despised;
91 but he royally revealed his steadfast intention 92 to Innocent, and from him he received 93 the first seal for his religious order.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Poi che la gente poverella crebbe 95 dietro a costui, la cui mirabil vita 96 meglio in gloria del ciel si canterebbe,
97 di seconda corona redimita 98 fu per Onorio da l’Etterno Spiro 99 la santa voglia d’esto archimandrita.
query.result:
94 After the poor people grew in number 95 behind this man, whose wondrous life 96 would be better sung to the glory of Heaven,
97 the holy desire of this archimandrite 98 was crowned with a second crown 99 by Honorius, from the Eternal Spirit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 E poi che, per la sete del martiro, 101 ne la presenza del Soldan superba 102 predicò Cristo e li altri che ’l seguiro,
103 e per trovare a conversione acerba 104 troppo la gente e per non stare indarno, 105 redissi al frutto de l’italica erba,
106 nel crudo sasso intra Tevero e Arno 107 da Cristo prese l’ultimo sigillo, 108 che le sue membra due anni portarno.
query.result:
100 And after, for the thirst of martyrdom, 101 in the presence of the proud Soldan 102 he preached Christ and the others who followed him,
103 and because he found the people too bitter for conversion 104 and in order not to labor in vain, 105 he returned to the fruit of the Italian soil,
106 on the harsh rock between the Tiber and the Arno 107 he received the final seal from Christ, 108 which his body bore for two years.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Quando a colui ch’a tanto ben sortillo 110 piacque di trarlo suso a la mercede 111 ch’el meritò nel suo farsi pusillo,
112 a’ frati suoi, sì com’ a giuste rede, 113 raccomandò la donna sua più cara, 114 e comandò che l’amassero a fede;
115 e del suo grembo l’anima preclara 116 mover si volle, tornando al suo regno, 117 e al suo corpo non volle altra bara.

query.result:
124 But his flock has become greedy for new food, 125 so that it cannot be 126 that it does not scatter in various directions;
127 and the more his distant and wandering sheep 128 go far from him, 129 the more they return to the fold empty of milk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Ben son di quelle che temono ’l danno 131 e stringonsi al pastor; ma son sì poche, 132 che le cappe fornisce poco panno.
query.result: 130 There are indeed some who fear harm 131 and keep close to the shepherd; but they are so few, 132 that their cowls provide little cloth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Or, se le mie parole non son fioche, 134 se la tua audïenza è stata attenta, 135 se ciò ch’è detto a la mente revoche,
136 in parte fia la tua voglia contenta, 137 perché vedrai la pianta onde si scheggia, 138 e vedra’ il corrègger che argomenta
139 “U’ ben s’impingua, se non si vaneggia”».
query.result:
133 Now, if my words are not feeble, 134 if your hearing has been attentive, 135 if you recall to mind what has been said,
136 your desire will be partly satisfied, 137 because you will see the plant from which the splinter comes, 138 and you will see the corrector who argues
139 “Where one fattens well, if one does not go astray”».
